A Copy of Mr. J. Allen's Diary during Journey from Toronto to Phoebus Forks Bank. April 15th to June 12th 1862.

We left Union Station Toronto via Grand Trunk Railway on Wednesday morning April 19th 1862 at 8:15 a.m., arriving at St. Paul on Saturday night at 11:00 P.M. April 23rd, at which place we were compelled to stay 16 days on account of a flood. We slept in cattle cars.

Most of the Officiators were very uncivil.

We started from St. Paul on Monday night May 6th at 11 P.M., arriving at Brandon on Sunday May 14th at 3 P.M.

Here Mr. John Stillborne buried one of his twins who had died on the way. On these six days trip I never knew or found such uncultivated and uncivilized conductors in all my life.

I asked one a question as to the journey being so slow and he replied "to hell with you and your questions". Another said to me "Be damned to your Question's you will get there some time this year".

We left Brandon on Thursday night at 6 P.M. May 16th. After travelling about four miles we rested. Here Mr. R.J. Fleming who had been with us thus far bade us goodbye, and went back, but most of our hearts were almost too full to return the compliment.

Friday May 17th. After travelling about four miles we went through 7 awful sloughs, travelling only 3 miles in ten hours.

May 20th. We only travelled 2½ miles. It was a terrible cold night with frost, had to cross six sloughs, had to use 10 yoke of oxen to a wagon. William Hartwell's wagon was stuck so we had to unload.

Sunday May 21st. We rested and had a good prayer meeting. Bless the Lord; He was with us and blessed us all; There was a good attendance at the Prayer Meeting and we all had a glorious time.

A Copy of Mr. Allen's Diary during Journey from Toronto to Pleasant Forks Bank - April 15th to June 12th 1862.

We left Union Station Toronto via Grand Trunk Railway on Wednesday morning April 19th 1862 at 8:15 a.m., arriving at St Paul on Saturday night at 11:30 p.m. April 22nd, at which place we stayed two days on account of a flood, much of the officials were away visiting relatives or sick in bed.

We started from St Paul on Monday night May 6th at 11 p.m., arriving at Brandon on Sunday May 14th at 3 p.m.

Here Mr. John Stillborne buried one of his twins who had died on the way.

On the six day's trip I never knew or heard much cultivated and uneducated conductors in all my life.

I asked one question as to the journey being so slow and so regulated.

"Will you go to hell with you and your questions?" Another asked me "Are damned to your question?"

"I will not get there some time this year."

No left Brandon on Thursday night at 6 p.m. May 18th. After travelling about four miles we rested. Here Mr. J. Fleming who had been with us three days, said he was going back, but most of our hearts were almost too full to return like company.

Friday May 18th. After travelling about four miles we went through 7 difficult bluffs, travelling only 6 miles in ten hours.

May 20th, we only travelled 22 miles, it was a terrible cold night with frost, had to cross six sloughs, had to use 10 yoke of oxen to a waggon. William Hartwell's wagon was stuck so we had to unload.

Sunday May 21st. We rested and had a good prayer meeting. Bless the Lord! He was with us and blessed us all; There was a good attendance at the Prayer Meeting and we all had a glorious time.
The meeting was held in Ward Bros Tent.

Monday May 23rd. We travelled 18 miles & went through 5 large sloughs.

Tuesday. WE travelled 14 miles & went through 7 large sloughs. One must have been a mile long.

Wed May 24th. We travelled 9 miles & went through 8 sloughs & on to Flatt Creek. We came through a terrible district of Sand Hills.

Arrived at 3 p.m. The oxen were terribly player out. Here we had to lighten our loads & left the things with a man in a tent.

Thursday May 25th. Travelled 18 miles. Passed through 5 large sloughs & went through 4 water courses. At Gopher Creek it was 4 ft deep, the weather has been fine for the last 5 days. Worked 18 hrs this day.

Friday May 26th. Traveled 18 or 19 miles. Went through 3 very large sloughs, in the morning of this day we crossed a river, in the evening had terrible drawing for 3 miles to the camp, we worked this day 15 hrs.

Saturday May 27th. Rested this day as Ward Bros had an ox sick.

Sunday May 28th. Rested. W.D. Fitzpatrick preached us a good sermon, his subject being "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ." All felt well.

Thank God:

Monday May 29th. Thavled 15 miles, crossed 6 rivers or some of them were very wide creeks, 10 alkali beds, 15 sloughs, a very heavy day, 15 hrs.

Tues May 30th. Travelled 14 miles, crossed 6 creeks, went through eight sloughs, & miles of heavy drawing, worked 15 hours to day.

Wed May 31st. Crossed 4 rivers, some of them very wide, one of them must have been more than 30 yds, as H Q Stillborn's rope & mine were each 6 ft & it took 10 logging chains to reach across, we just got out of the river when starting up Mr John Stillborn's Goat got run over. How it was the poor thing wasn't killed was a mystery to all, but she got over it.

We went through 12 sloughs to day & travelled 15 miles & worked 17 hrs.
The meeting was held in Ward Bros Tent.

Monday May 23rd. We travelled 18 miles & went through 5 large sloughs. One must have been a mile long.

Tuesday. We travelled 14 miles & went through 7 large sloughs. We came through a terrible district of Sand Hills.

Friday May 26th. Traveled 18 or 19 miles. Went through 5 very large sloughs, in the morning of this day we crossed a river. In the evening had terrible drawing for 3 miles to the camp, we worked this day 15 hrs.

Saturday May 27th. Rested this day as Ward Bros had an ox sick.

Sunday May 28th. Rested. W.D. Fitzpatrick preached us a good sermon, his subject being "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ." All felt well.

Thank God: Monday May 29th. Travelled 15 miles, crossed 6 rivers or some of them were very wide creeks, 10 alkali beds, 15 sloughs, a very heavy day, 15 hrs.

Tuesday May 30th. Traveled 14 miles, crossed 6 creeks, went through eight sloughs, & miles of heavy drawing, worked 15 hours today.

Wednesday May 31st. Crossed 4 rivers, some of them very wide, one of them gust have been more than 30 yds, ash Q Stillborn's rope & mine were each 6 ft & it took 10 logging chains to reach across, we just got out of the river when starting up Mr John Stillborn's boat got run over, how it was the poor thing wasn't killed we & ministry to all, but she got over it.

We went through 13 sloughs to day & travelled 15 miles & worked 17 hrs.
Thurs June 1st
Went through 7 most terrible streams today, it took us up to our waist in water for an hour. I stood on one side of the water course & Jack McKee on the other side handling the oxen in the stream. Out here young Johnnie Webster thought he would face the stream with H Q Stillborn's yoke of oxen, but unknown to him the side went straight down, the oxen plunged in & Johnny flew over their heads, & called for help, Jack McKee laughed at him & said "hold on to the oxen Johnny", but Johnny replied "can't you see I'm off & in the water?" Only travelled 10 miles & worked 15 hrs.

Friday June 2nd
Crossed 4 heavy streams, 16 sloughs, five miles awful heavy drawing, went through great flats knee deep with water, it must have been near two miles through it. We traveled 11 miles today, and worked 12 hours.

Saturday June 3rd
We went through one mile of alkali bed and 4 sloughs, it was heavy drawing all the way, we crossed one large river in which 4 wagons stuck and had to be unloaded. Travelled only 3½ miles & worked 15 hours.

Sunday June 4th
To day we rested, Mr Thos Todd preached a good sermon at night, & a splendid feeling we all had, Thank God for it!

Monday June 5th
Went through 20 sloughs & 4 streams, drawing was very heavy all the way, travelled 14 miles & worked 15 hours.

Tuesday June 6th
Went through 18 sloughs & crossed 6 streams, heavy drawing all the way. Here H Q Stillborn lost his dog, travelled 10 miles and worked 14 hours.

Wednesday June 7th
Crossed 5 rivers & 9 sloughs, travelled 18 miles & worked 16 hours.

Thursday June 8th
Went through 4 large streams & 4 sloughs, went down a tremendous ravine 1½ miles long into the Qu'Appelle Valley.

wagons went over the hill, wagon oxen and all, breaking his brother's house stove. At the time I was lame with a bad knee, so I asked Jedgwick and Walter Willis to carry me to look at the hill, when I seen it I said that will do take me back to the waggon and drive my waggon to the hill, and then lock my off hind wheel. Mr Stillborn at once cried out "Mr Allen you are locking the wrong wheel", I replied "I replied No.No. always lock on the side to the hill" or you will be drawn down the hill. I drove myself down and I was the first down. When his time came for going down the hill he persisted in locking his nigh wheel with the result named, the others followed my example and locked the off wheel and all came down all right. At the bottom of this hill was a muskeg into which one of Mr Webster's oxen ran for water and got mired, & would have been killed, but he got my oxen & pulled him out. We travelled 16 this day in 15 hours.

Friday June 9th. Travelled only 4 miles & got across the Qu'Appelle River,. It took us just 10 hours to cross that river, we worked that day just 14 hours.

Saturday June 10th This was a good but terribly hot, we went through 4 small sloughs & travelled 14 miles in 12 hours.

Sunday June 11th. We rested today by a large lake at which Mr C. Robison from Cumberland, England the man with a mule and a ox for a team, preached to us a good encouraging sermon.

Monday June 12th We set out at 2.40 a.m. a tremendous draw all day with 9 or 10 sloughs to go through,. WE arrived in camp at top of hill at Pheasant Forks at 6 p.m. in township 21 sec#14, We travelled the distance in 15 hours & 20 minutes, At dinner my knee burst, which had been bad for 9 days,. My fellow travelers like good brothers came to my aid, doing all my heavy work, for all of which I am deeply grateful.

and cannot possibly forget it.

Tuesday June 13th. I spent 8 hours looking over land with view of choosing homestead and fixed on section 30 township 21.

Wednesday June 14th. Spent 8 hours again for purpose of inspection and still like sect 30 better than any I have seen.

Thursday June 15th. Settled to have Section 30 N.E. Quarter.

I should state here that nearly all if not all the tongues of our wagons were broken, & almost every logging chain.

Friday & Saturday June 16-17th we rested & we all were in need of it.

Sunday June 18th. I preached in the morning, had a most attentive large company & a most precious time for which I do thank God.

Our text was: "I have given you an example. Christ therefore was our example.

Monday June 19th. We moved from the Forks to our respective homesteads.

Tuesday June 20th. Began plowing.

Wednesday June 21st. Sowed 2 bush of oats. ½ bush peas & 8 bushel of potatoes, all of which came up first class.

I sowed the oats & peas on the grass & broke them in, they came through the sod on July 4th, just 11 days after sowing.

Note to his friends Mr. and Mrs. Jno Stillborn.

"Now my dear friends I think I have given you a fair statement of all we went through. There may be few little things I did not see, so you must take the statement as in the main correct, as far as my observations.

God grant we may never have another journey like it. With kind christian love to you all, not forgetting the dear young men. Oh; how I did enjoy myself with them & you all, I do trust that they each will become burning & shining lights for our Dear Savior.

Just tell them that I shall not forget them at family prayer.

I have not been so well these last few days, the ride shook my poor back but I trust in our Heavenly Father, I know he will not leave His poor old servant. If I can I will send Dear Hector a few words that will help him with his paper.

I hope you can make this out, for my hand begins to tremble so that I can't do as I would, but am thankfull I can do as well as I do.

Mrs Allen wishes to be remembered to Mrs Stillborn and you all.

we are yours

In Jesus Christ

J.& S.A. Allen.
